headline.main: Ideas & Trends; Choice Is Good. Yes, No or Maybe?

docs.abstract: Consumer choice has claimed prominent new position as a policy tool; it has become prescription for everything from improving public schools to paring bloated health care costs to saving Social Security; critics say that expanding consumers' options is not always good idea, and that sometimes government should choose for them; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: CHOICE is the driving force of capitalism. Choosy consumers determine what products and companies thrive or die as they pick among tubes of toothpaste or plans for cellphone service. Choice fuels competition, innovation and efficiency. These days, consumer choice has claimed a prominent new position as a policy tool: the prescription for everything from improving public schools to paring bloated health care costs to saving Social Security.
docs.snippet: As choice is brought to bear on the nation's problems, critics point out that expanding consumers' options is not always a good idea.

docs.abstract: Jane Stern reviews book Fat Girl: A True Story by Judith Moore; photo; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: FAT GIRL A True Story. By Judith Moore. 196 pp. Hudson Street Press. $21.95.
docs.snippet: Judith Moore has been overweight all her life, and makes no apologies.

headline.main: Maker of Wrinkle Treatment To Buy Breast Implant Leader

docs.abstract: Medicis Pharmaceutical agrees to acquire Inamed, market leader in breast implants for women, in deal valued at $2.8 billion (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Medicis Pharmaceutical, which makes prescription treatments for people who cannot stand their wrinkles, has agreed to acquire Inamed, a rival better known as the market leader in breast implants for women. The deal, for stock and cash, is valued at $2.8 billion. The two companies told analysts in a conference call yesterday that they expected the deal to create an ''aesthetics powerhouse'' able to meet expanding demand for products to preserve a youthful appearance.
